item.description: As a result, we mistake wanting for happiness, and we mistake our stress as the feeling that is occuring as a result of not having attained the thing that had our dopamine firing in the first place.

Sources: The Willpower Instinct - Kelly Mcgonigal - notes Heart rate variability is an indicator of stress. Basically, your heart places greater emphasis on beating consistently when it is under duress.
Is it fair to say I’m desocialized? Or is it more fair to say I have lots of people who enjoy my company and would call me social & socialized?

item.description: Ashtanga has been fun. I found my way to it last summer, with a youtube video while I was inside on a rainy day.

item.description: A Cyrillic name (I think?) that way back the etymological line, came from the same place as Jonathan. BogDan, JonaThan. Adds up.

item.title: Deal with anxiety by leaning into your anxiety
item.description: A neccesary aspect of growth is learning to sit with emotions, and giving them the space to be felt properly.

item.title: Deploying Quartz to the Web
item.description: GitHub Pages Quartz is designed to be effortless to deploy. If you forked and cloned Quartz directly from the repository, everything should already be good to go!

item.title: Earth - New Content Available!
item.description: New content has been made available for the classic RPG and world simulator, EARTH. The creators of Earth, Nick and Celine, announced today they moved up the release of EARTH 2050-2100 to fill the scenario gap now that Humanity has achieved critical mass, discovered compound-level time travel almost 30 years before schedule, and set the stage for global environmental disaster almost 200,000 years before predicted.

item.title: Editing Content in Quartz
item.description: Editing Quartz runs on top of Hugo so all notes are written in Markdown. Obsidian I recommend using Obsidian as a way to edit and grow your digital garden.

item.title: Exercise is restorative
item.description: Exercise trains the muscular and cardiovascular system in efficiency and strength. It prolongs our life. It makes us more capable in day to day life.

item.title: Feeling our feelings
item.description: Trying to supress what we are thinking leads to a concept called Ironic Rebound (wherein the thing you are trying to push away comes back with more intensity).

item.title: Responding to 'failures' with self-criticism results in that behaviour being more likely to repeat itself
item.description: Self compassion is important, as it is a way to lower your HRV ([[HRV is your willpower fuel tank]]). It is also important because forgiving yourself for ‘transgressing’ is far more effective in curtailing future transgressions than criticism and self-hate.

item.title: Restaurants Whitehorse
item.description: I made this May 2021 after a roommate’s self-pity about the lack of food options in Whitehorse made me curious about whether the city has over 100 restaurants

item.title: Stress and Being reminded of our mortality brings us into a dopamine-craving state
item.description: When we are reminded of our mortality, or become stressed, we become more impulsive and seek a reward. Instinctively, that reward is a lust for dopamine.

item.title: The Licensing and Halo effect
item.description: The licensing effect refers to our propensity to allow ourselves to ‘sin’ after first doing something ‘good.’ For example, we may decide to go for salad instead of burger when we’re watching our diets.

item.title: The luxury of willpower, and building the foundations of it
item.description: The idea of willpower is pretty inane, when you think about it. Some chemical process going about inside you is deciding whether you will or will not do things that you want to do.

item.description: Two weeks ago, it went from -49 to +2 in one week. it always snows right when it starts warming up.

item.title: Visualizing the future moves you out of a dopamine dependent state
item.description: We rarely think of the future, because we are constantly wrapped in the now. By placing more emphasis on the now, we become dopamine-dependent.
